posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

>>14605148
>The usual answer given for this question is 'Domino Theory', but a vague statement from Eisenhower feels like a pretty high school-level answer to this.
The Truman Doctrine and Domino Theory should not have their importance dismissed when it comes to analyzing the development and implementation of American containment policy in the Cold War.

Of course, those polices, alone, don't fully explain the U.S. fixation on Vietnam. We must also pay might to American fears that they would lose the trust of their allies if they left South Vietnam in the lurch and that unilerally withdrawing from a campaign they had already put so much time, energy, manpower, and treasure into would decimate American presitge.

By the time of the Nixon administration, the United States very much wanted to withdraw from the situation but they needed "peace with honor" to diminish any loss of that aforementioned American prestige. However, their antagonists didn't seem likely to agree to any mutual withdrawal of troops, for example, which put the United States in even more of a bind. The policy of Vietnamization came about as a result so as to place the weight of the fighting on the Vietnamese in hopes of throwing out any accusation that American left South Vietnam in the lurch and to increase the possibility of South Vietnam being able to hold out on its own making past American efforts in the region worthwhile sacrifices that were needed to successfully contain communism while, at the same time, diminishing the need for and usage of actual American combat troops in the region.

>>14604336
'Europe' originally referred to a specific part of the SE of the continent, in Greece.
'Asia' originally referred to a specific part of the West of that continent, in Turkey.
'Africa' originally referred to a specific part of the North of that continent, around Tunisia.

The terms all expanded 'away' from one another. I.e. Europe was North and West of Africa and Asia, so it grew out of Greece until it was applied to everything between Athens and Iceland.

Three problems.
1. Soviets would never capitulate since Germany wasnt interested in any terms of surrender.

2. To get the Soviet industry back to pre-invasion level would likely take years, setting up a whole new logisticial infrastructure repairing, maintaining, extracting, shipping, refining, distripute raw material.

3. Building a surface navy almost from scratch to a level that could match the Royal Navy would likely take a decade. Not only that, but Germany also lacked any condition for amphibious operations. They didnt have a doctrine, training, experience, industry, equiptment, or the capability to gain all that within a few years.
Operation Sealion was a pure fantasy that not even Hitler believed in. The original plan essentially called for using massive pontoons and river barges, makeshift material which could never sustain such a massive logistical and military endeavor. Operation Sealion was tested at the Sandhurst military academy in the 1970s which further proved the overwhelming catastrophe for any German attempt.

To conclude. The fall of the USSR would in itself begin a long process of annexation and incorporating, in which German resources would be extremely strained since she no longer recieved the vital trade with USSR, and because the Royal Navy blockade would now take a much more heavier toll on the economy, and now also had to be redirected to rebuild newly conquered areas.
By this time, USA would likely dramatically ramp up its committment to the European front.
Also, by the time German military industry and operational capability to invade Britain would be complete, its likely that the allies had long already developed the nuclear bomb.

Drawn up alongside Jim Morrison and Johnny Rotten, Tito arguably had the better claim to be an icon.

posts.com: >Tito’s popularity with young people was genuine and widespread (although far from universal), and it left a significant mark on popular culture. One of the most popular rock-pop songs of the early Eighties was Count on Us (Računajte na nas) by Novi Sad band Rani Mraz, released in 1979 and much quoted during and after his final illness. “Some may think we are carried by the wrong flow/Because we listen to records and play rock and roll” (Sumnjaju neki da nosi nas pogrešan tok/Jer slušamo ploče i sviramo rok) went the refrain, driving home the message that electric guitars and denim jeans were by no means incompatible with Titoist idealism. The song was written by Đorđe Balašević, who went on to become an “urban chansonnier” (his own words) of great poetic subtlety, delivering social criticism as well as wistful balladeering. Another song that served as soundtrack to the immediate post-Tito years was Comrade Tito We Pledge Ourselves to You (Druže Tito mi ti se kunemo), a song which had its origins in the Partisan period but which became a radio hit when covered by pop heartthrob Zdravko Čolić in 1977. Re-released in spring 1980 when Tito was already in hospital, it went on to sell over 300,000 copies.

>Stuck in trenches for days, weeks, even months

>Can hear rats gnawing on the remains of your comrades in the no-man's-land
>Nonstop artillery strikes; shrapnel flying everywhere
>Mustard and chlorine gas attacks
>Fighter planes strafing you
>Mines being detonated beneath you
>Rampant disease; no antibiotics yet
>Terrifying night raids
>Getting ordered into a frontal assault and getting ripped apart by machine guns
>Or slipping into a crater and drowning in a mix of mud, blood, and chemicals
>Tanks are slow, clunky, and not terribly effective until late in the war
>Go into shell-shock and get executed for cowardice

The Flood was based on a local flood in the Persian Gulf that occurred around 3000 BCE which swallowed up the coasts. A local farmer managed to survive the flood by building a small bowl-shaped boat with a small hut inside (I would post a pic but I can't find it I keep getting Christfag shit when I search for it), brought some of his animals and rode out the storm. The story was passed on through oral tradition gradually exaggerating the stakes up to the Sumerian story of Utnapishtim, which was the template for all flood myths in the middle east. Noah's ark is the Semitic variant of that story.

Sodom was most likely an explanation for the Dead Sea, a large salty sea in the middle of the Levant with little vegetation surrounding it. People at time believed that only a divine act could cause such devastation such rationalized that it must have once been a city that was destroyed for angering the gods. The act that caused it was the people being inhospitable to God's emissaries; a mob trying to rape the Angels which angered God so much he destroyed the city and left the surrounding country desolate forever. The story of Sodom is a warning to be hospitable to your guests because if you don't bad things will happen.

There is some truth to these stories, but not the truth kikes or Christfags are trying to sell you.

>It seems that in the early centuries of Christianity no distinctive dress was adopted by ecclesiastics. Many indications point to this conclusion ... The most explicit testimony is that afforded by a letter of Pope Celestine in 428 to certain bishops of Gaul, in which he rebukes them for wearing attire which made them conspicuous, and lays down the rule that "we [the bishops and clergy] should be distinguished from the common people [plebe] by our learning, not by our clothes; by our conduct, not by our dress; by cleanness of mind, not by the care we spend upon our person" (Mansi, "Concilia", IV, 465). In the East it would seem to have been the custom for ascetics and philosophers, whether Christian or not to affect a special habit, but the Christian clergy generally did not profess asceticism in this distinctive way, and were content to wear the birrus (byros) like the laity about them. ... "If any man", says [the Council of Gangra (340)], "uses the pallium [cloak] upon account of an ascetic life, and, as if there be some holiness in that, condemns those who with reverence use the birrus and other garments that are commonly worn, let him be anathema" (Hefele-Leclercq, "Hist. des Conc.", I, 1037). At the other extremity of Christendom the documents that survive concerning St. Patrick and other early Celtic bishops present them to us as habitually dressed in the casula (chasuble), which was at that time not a distinctively liturgical attire, but simply an outer garment commonly worn by the humbler classes.

>>14593228
Life was hard for peasants. They owed a certain amount of work to their lord in return for the right to grow crops and raise animals for themselves. This work tax is w here the nonsense about only working a third of the year comes from. The average peasant did not have money, everything was paid for in kind. This makes it very hard to calculate their wealth, but during the early period it was not easy to get your hands on anything not made locally.
A peasant's dwelling was a large single room which would be shared with their entire family and their animals during the winter. Beds were made of straw. They were generally illiterate. The village priest was also drawn from the lower classes and often had a poor understanding of Latin and theology compared to more noble born priests and bishops. A peasant could not leave the manor without permission from their lord. While under some forms of serfdom a lord could force you to fight, especially as time went on, this burden fell on freemen and later professional mercenaries. On the other hand it was not unheard of for villages to suffer raids from knights without wars to fight. Hunting was for nobles, a peasant could get in big trouble if they were caught hunting. Fishing however was OK. Most meat peasants ate was preserved. They did get some meat and fish but the vast majority of their diet was grain based. People didn't live much shorter lives than now, through many children died young, and women died in childbirth at much higher rates. Only members of the nobility would be as tall as people today, almost everyone was short by today's standards.

>>14601925
Yall really should use the term serf and not peasant. Peasant is a farmer. A farmer can be a bound to the land, or a free renter, or a free landowner, or even a member of the gentry could call himself a farmer if he works closely with the production of his land even on a managerial level of other farmers on his land. Being a farmer is not a bad thing. Oliver Cromwell would have called himself a farmer for an example, although the period is wrong it gives you an idea of the meaning of a farmer into the early modern period. Also when we are talking about "peasants" where in Europe are we talking makes a big difference in terms of class. A "peasant" in England is different from one in a French kingdom who is different from a central European kingdom and so on. Also you have to consider regions where farming was poor. Many Scots and Irish "peasants" would not have "farming" skills but pastoral skills with livestock.

>wake up at 5, milk cows (if you were rich enough to own cows)
>brekkie time
>plough, sow or harvest fields for 3-4 months a year, in this case you'd gather up your family and work until dawn with a hearty vespers in between and dinner afterwards
>if no field work is required, you would instead improve your farm, fix up broken stuff, cut wood, or do the corvée labor agreed upon in your tenant contract with either the church or your lord
>in case its winter, and there's no work apart from tending to animals and household chores, you'd do cottage industry labor like producing clothes, crafts, stuff like cheese or beer, etc.
>get wasted with your friends in the evening and have sex with the wife
>go to bed
In case its some church holiday or social event:
>get up at 5 and milk the cows, get brekkie and do household chores
>go to church
>have a party or whatever in the afternoon and evening

Not too bad overall, but you essentially have no "free time" in the modern sense, as in vacation days or taking time off. I described the life of a rather rich farmer btw, in some situations you'd also have to do side jobs to scrape by, which would be very stressful

>>14593228
As long as you weren't in the migration era or during the plague, you were pretty okay. The worst times if year were harvest and sowing, though harvest was worse depending on if you used a billhook or scythe. You spent a couple of weeks doing fairly hard labor supported by your family and community, then as you finished you would have less and less to do. Pretty much what amounts to daily chores with feeding the animals, turning compost, and maybe a few house repairs. Sometimes they got odd jobs here and there to give themselves a bit extra breathing room.
Overall the amount of work they did was very hit or miss with large gaps of off time when it was out of sowing or harvest. People were busy to be sure but it was mostly light labor or something that took their fancy. Its a lot different then something you HAVE to wake up and do for 8 hours a day.
>t. Homesteaded for 4 years.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>14606095
The US was never entirely self-sufficient. The British imposed a monopoly on trade with the colonies, and tried to control what could be imported into the colonies and pissed off the colonies when they started taxing it.

The Jeffersonian had this idealistic image of a yeoman agrarian America, but it turns out plantations, factories, and merchants were far more profitable than subsistence farming. Even the War of 1812 with the British blockade made the Americans miserable being "self-sufficient" because trade and imports (both cheaper goods and luxury items) were more important than growing your own cabbages.

Americans had no desire to really be self-sufficient as a whole. Frontier life was a way for people who couldn't find jobs or cheap land in the east to achieve some economic independence. Once they established themselves, they began to buy more luxury items and imports.

That was where nationalism as a political force came from and why it's an invention of the late 18th/early 19th century.

Classic "nationalism" (built on the city-state) existed a long time ago. Like Rome and Greece, each state was rather small, had privileged citizens who had say in politics and constituted the majority in the army, contrary to slaves, servants, barbarians, etc. In that circumstance, nationalism for the "citizens" existed and thrived.

As for modern nationalism, it emerged in late 18th century as a popular and revolutionary movement marked by a communal identification with one’s nation (i.e. "the Irish" or "the Turks"), and while they often looked back on ancient history to draw inspiration, they included things like now-modern political campaigns to raise awareness and mobilize people and establish the modern nation-state.

Hobsbawm defines nationalism as the ideology that the political and national units should coincide.

(1) He views the nation as a changing, evolving, modern construct that is brought into being by nationalism, and not the other way around.

>>14597165

I think there is some confusion that english speakers encounter about the notion of "ethnic" in the classical greek world. The word "Ethnos" is litterally a ethnic group, you might say this is a "race' , but that still doesn't cut it. Greeks used ethnos to signify basically a tribal group of people. However because Greeks spoke different dialects of Greek, and because they were never unified politically and defined their differences in what political systems they used there was never a Greek nation in the ethno-political sense nor exactly in the precice cultural sense. Rather the interesting thing with Greeks is that although they had no uniform national-ethnic identity , they certainly used a term as an exonym to define anyone who was not Greek, that is the "barbarian". Thus this exonym was the defining factor, rather than defining the characteristics of a "Greek race", since this would devolve into too many confusions. For example Plato says that the "ideal" Republic would be a unified "Greek state", but that is mainly to protect the Greeks from being enslaved by barbarians. Thus the classical Greeks intellectuals did not recognize the inborn state of nationhood and polities of barbarians as some kind of natural political entity (like John Locke would argue), but as theologically opposed to them. This was not so different in how the Jews defined themselves against the "idolatrus" non-Jews.

>>14601692
The problem is that you, like other anons ITT are conflating "nation" with "State", and the things you say to show that there were no pre-modern nations instead only prove that there were no pre-modern States. You treat the words "nation" and "State" as if they were functionally the same and one implied the other necessarily.
Does a nation require a State to exist? If the answer is yes, then let me ask you, are the Kurds a nation or not?
Does ever State have a related nation? When Germany was divided during the Cold war, did a West German belong to a different nation than an East German?
If a nation is intrinsically related to a State, let me ask you, if a Frenchman moves out of France, is he still a Frenchman? And if he has a child in, say, Germany, but said child is homeschooled, does the child belong to the French nation, the German nation or to neither at all?
I say that the nation as a concept was/is related to the State, for sure, but that it is independent of it and that it appeared long before. The names of many contemporary nations have existed since ancient times, and people recognized themselves as belonging to a nation, and recognized others as belong to the same or to a different nation. A nation is a cultural community, not a political community. You can have many nations within a single polity and members of a nation spread out in many different polities.
To name one example, the Teutonic order was formed by people from many different cities located in what's modern day Germany back in the Middle Ages, and the people from those lands referred to the order as "Deutscher Ritterorden" ("the German order of knights"). They could tell that even if they came from different cities, they all spoke a similar language and had a similar culture and were collectively distinct from the people from other places in Europe like France or Italy, even if some regions of said countries were part of the HRE just like the German cities.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>14605117
>Or Westeros' historiography is in a truly abysmal state and most of that world's known history is a complete fabrication
Compare this to Scandinavia history.
Because the Norse didn't write anything down before Christian conversation, we don't know anything about pre-Christian kings of Denmark, Sweden, and Norway. Only sources come from sagas that contradict each other and were written down only after three centuries after the conversion.
Take Harald Fairhair for instance, his historicity has been brought into question, because there is no solid evidence he ever existed, and many historians think he is a proto-type to justify the reign of the first Christian king of Denmark, Harald Bluetooth.
Then you have insane people like 12/13th century Saxo Grammaticus who fabricated the entire Danish line of kings predating the birth of Jesus (see Gasta Danorum).

Is it really a stretch to assume that some North had Saxo Grammaticus of their own who fabricated a bullshit line of kings for the Starks and it was accepted as factual?

>All that "Catholic Church" really means is the universal embodiment of Christ's Body of followers.

From the beginning the Catholic Church has had a hierarchical, episcopal, visible structure, as testified in the 100s by St. Ignatius of Antioch and St. Irenaeus.

By the year 180, apostolic succession was understood as the sure indicator of orthodoxy. Thus St Irenaeus of Lyons, writing against the Gnostics in that year:
>Since, however, it would be very tedious, in such a volume as this, to reckon up the successions of all the Churches, we do put to confusion all those who... whether by an evil self-pleasing, by vainglory, or by blindness and perverse opinion, assemble in unauthorized meetings; [we do this, I say,] by indicating that tradition derived from the apostles, of the very great, the very ancient, and universally known Church founded and organized AT ROME by the two most glorious apostles, Peter and Paul; as also [by pointing out] the faith preached to men, which comes down to our time by means of the successions of the bishops.

>For it is A MATTER OF NECESSITY that EVERY CHURCH SHOULD AGREE WITH THIS CHURCH [i.e. Rome], on account of its preeminent authority.
-St Irenaeus, Against Heresies 3.3.2, 180 AD (emphasis added)

But, it may be added, if we wish to locate the Church founded by Jesus, we need to locate the one that has the four chief marks or qualities of his Church, as set forth in the Nicene Creed. St. Irenaeus emphasized only one of these: that the Church must be apostolic.

But the true Church is also: One, Holy, and Catholic, in addition to being apostolic. And the Catholic Church is the only Church which possesses those four marks. By contrast, the Eastern Orthodox churches are neither one nor Catholic, being primarily ethnic churches.

posts.com: The thing I think Francis has been trying to do is to ensure it is understood that those who are in irregular situations, such as homosexuals, divorced/remarried Christians, etc. do understand that they have a place in the Church and are made welcome there; but *not* in the sense that their sin is accepted, or that they are not called to repentance, but in the sense that they are there to struggle against their sin equally with everyone else and thus have a legitimate presence even if they are not always successful. So for example, a homosexual who at times fails in his struggle is not doing something different in principle from one who fails at some other sin, but the homosexual is de facto excluded where the other may not be. Francis is not trying to advocate for a change in doctrine, which is clear from his opposition to the heretical German bishops, who are doing such a thing. This is what his idea of being welcoming is about, though, to make sure the church, as spiritual hospital, is actually giving aid to all of those who need her, rather than kicking them out because their situation is particularly distasteful. To this end I think he's done some unfortunate things that can give the wrong message, but I think this is what he's actually trying to do, and if you interpret him in this way it starts to make sense. Maybe I'm wrong.

Hebrews 1:8 is one of the more commonly used scriptures for trinitarian “evidence” in spite of (in reality, because of) its obvious ambiguity. Heb. 1:8 in the King James Version (AV or KJV) is rendered:


“But unto the son he saith, thy throne, O God, is for ever and ever: a sceptre of righteousness is the sceptre of thy kingdom.”


Since “he saith” and the second “is” (found after “righteousness”) in the above verse are not actually found in the original manuscripts and have been added by the KJV translators, they are found in italics in most printings of the KJV.


But more importantly (as a quick glance into any interlinear Greek-English New Testament will show) the first “is” (found after “God”) in the above verse is also not in the original manuscripts but has been added by some modern translators.


Yes, literally the original NT Greek manuscripts read: “Toward but the son the throne of you the god into the age of the age.”


No one should deny that the title theos (NT Greek word meaning “God,” “god,” “mighty one,” “divine,” etc.) can be applied to Jesus (at least in the writings of John - see the DEF and BOWGOD studies), just as it was applied in the scriptures to angels, judges of Israel, Moses, and (according to some trinitarian authorities) even the kings of Israel.


But theos is never applied to Jesus with the most high sense that is given only to the Almighty, Most High, only true God. So it could, perhaps, have been used at Heb. 1:8 in its positive secondary sense: “Your throne, o mighty one [theos], is ...”. This seems even more probable when we remember that Paul is really quoting from Ps. 45:6.

In choosing the text they believed to be closest to the original manuscript of the book of Hebrews, the UBS committee looked at the very oldest and best manuscripts still in existence today. Several methods helped them decide what is probably the original wording. One, of course, is how many of the very oldest and best manuscripts agree.


Another method is to determine which of the variations were most likely to have been changed by later copyists. For instance, when a NT writer is referring to an OT quotation, he often has it worded slightly differently from the exact quote in the Septuagint (Paul is especially noted for this).


So, if one NT manuscript has an OT scripture quoted exactly as it appears in the Septuagint, and another has a slightly different wording, the manuscript that differs slightly is more likely to have the proper, original wording. (Later copyists strongly tended to “correct” the original NT manuscripts by making their OT quotes conform exactly to the wording in the Septuagint version.)


Another consideration is that later Church copyists would often change the wording of a scripture if it seemed to contradict a teaching of the Roman Church.[1] Therefore, if the wording of an ancient manuscript seems to contradict a later teaching of the Roman Church, it is more likely to have the original wording than another ancient manuscript which (at the same verse) seems to agree with that Church teaching.

It was the very last word of Heb. 1:8 that caused a “considerable degree of doubt” among those textual scholars. This very last word was either the NT Greek word sou (translated into English as “of you” or “your”) or autou (translated “of him” or “his”).


Why is it so important? If, however, sou (“your”) was the original wording, then it could be translated either way. Obviously, then, a trinitarian would strongly prefer the reading of sou. [See end note 4]


In discussing this problem the UBS Committee noted that most of the very oldest and best manuscripts (p46 - circa 200 A.D.; 'Aleph' - 4th century; and B - 4th century) all agree that the original wording was “his (autou) kingdom.”


They also noted that later manuscripts which read “your (sou) kingdom” are now in agreement with the corresponding passage in the Greek OT Septuagint! (Remember that the UBS Committee recognizes, as do most Bible scholars, that the NT manuscript that differs slightly from the Septuagint is more likely to be correct than another one which perfectly agrees because copyists strongly tended to deliberately “correct” Septuagint quotes they found in the NT .)

>Greek Orthodox Patriarch of Jerusalem Dositheos Notaras (1641–1707) wrote: "It is an established custom and ancient tradition, known to all, that the Most Holy Patriarchs give the absolution certificate (συγχωροχάρτιον – synchorochartion) to the faithful people … they have granted them from the beginning and still do."

>The practice of issuing indulgences ... received official confirmation at the Constantinople Council of 1727. ... "The Confession of Faith" from the Council, the text of which was compiled by Patriarch Chrysanthus of Jerusalem and was signed by Patriarchs Paisius II of Constantinople, Sylvester of Antioch, and Chrysanthus of Jerusalem ... said, "The power of the forgiveness of sins, which is termed by the Eastern Church of Christ Absolution Certificates when given in writing, but by the Latins Indulgences, is given to the Holy Church by Christ. These Absolution Certificates are issued in the whole Catholic Church by the four most holy Patriarchs: Constantinople, Alexandria, Antioch, and Jerusalem."

>Indulgences as a means of enrichment were condemned at the Council of Constantinople in the year 1838.

>>14603513
It's true that elohim is a plural form, but it is understood as the singular god anyway. Most of the OT uses either yahweh, its abreviation (think yah from halleluyah, which is ה').

In Ex. 34:6, for example, we have וַיַּעֲבֹ֨ר יְהֹוָ֥ה (where the second word, again right to left, is "yahweh", and not elohim). That tends to be true through exodus. It's also true in later genesis.

Elohim is used in many places, however. For example genesis starts with
>בְּרֵאשִׁ֖ית בָּרָ֣א אֱלֹהִ֑ים
The 3rd word (right to left) is "elohim".
Elohim is not used exclusively to refer to god. Beside being used also to refer to the gods of other peoples, it is also used to refer to kings, angels, and judges. The same is true in the greek (theos) in the NT.

In addition you have to realize that elohim is not used alone that often. In Genesis 1:1 that's true, but you get
>וַיִּיצֶר֩ יְהוָ֨ה אֱלֹהִ֜ים
which is rendered as "god yahweh created" (hebrew translations will use "god adonai or god YHWH").

Jews consider that the plural refers to God taking council with His Angels (who He had created by this point) before creating Adam.

Thoughts on Manichaeism? They were like a sub-Christian Gnostic Church/religion that began in the 3rd century by their prophet Mani, a Gnostic from Babylonia (modern day Iraq).

He said his divine twin showed him that a God of light was battling a realm of darkness and that humans bodies were made out of evil matter but their souls were from the light world where their God lived. They had a particular focus on the story of the Watchers and the Nephilim from 1 Enoch. Ritual ablution with water was an important practice in Manichaeism akin to baptism. Their primary scriptures included some Old Testament and New Testament Apocrypha and the writings of Mani.

Manichaeism combined aspects of Gnosticism, Christianity, Judaism, Buddhism, and Zoroastrianism into a new religion. Jesus, Mani, Buddha, and Zoroaster were regarded as the greatest prophets that ever lived. Jesus was considered the greatest prophet and identical to the divine Christ from the realm of the light God, and Mani was considered an Apostle of Christ and Seal of the Prophets.

Mani starved to death in prison while in Persia. Mani had at one time made a trip to India where he studied Hinduism and Buddhism. Mani spoke Aramaic as his first language and Persian as a second. He was primarily Iranian by race.

The Manichean Church was divided into three groups: the Catechumens, the Elect, and the Clergy. The clergy themselves were divided into four groups: The Head, the Apostles, the Bishops, and the Elders. Manichaeism spread as far as China at one point.

>>14601852
I've said a few times I used to have a paper that talked about this in more depth and like the agricultural carrying capacity of the valley at the time of Spanish contact, but I lost it and haven't been able to relocate it.

I DID recently find the paper "Settlement Pattern and Chinampa Agriculture at Tenochtitlan" by Edward E. Calnek, which is interesting, because it basically goes against the prevailing information you'll find online and even in seemingly reputable sources about Chinampas:

- The paper makes a distinction between the staked out land plots in the city, and the actual agricultural chinampa farms (which were thinner strips next to them, and occupied less space

- It comes to the conclusion that Chinampas weren't actually that agriculturally productive and wouldn't have been used to even sustain a quarter of a family's dietary intake in most cases (though some parts of Tenochtitlan and specific residences (which actually don't seem to be as small and consistently single-roomed as people seem to think/often assume) had proportionally larger or smaller chinampas), and were instead likely used for supplementary fresh herbs and vegetables

Among some other stuff I forgot about. It also references a large dataset the author has access to of maps and land survey information that helps reconstruct floorplans of residences and land plots in Tenochtitlan based on colonial period records and modern construction in Mexico City, and for obvious reasons I am quite interested in that data, but the paper is from the 70s and I suspect tho can't confirm the author is deceased.

1/2

The only accurate ones are really 23andme and Ancestry.com. They will match your DNA against modern populations and tell you which ones you are composed of. They also give you traits and stuff, so 23andme will tell you if you are genetically likely to have male patterrn baldness for instance. Most other companies, like OP's myheritage will straight give inaccurate results. So it's not really worth it unless you're REALLY interested.

We are not justified by the works of the Law, i.e. made righteous in the eyes of God. The Law refers to those specific marks of the covenant given to Moses for the children of Israel, and refers to things such as sabbaths, circumcision of the flesh, animal sacrifices, kosher, etc. They are not bad in and of themselves, but they are not part of the New Covenant, which is prophecized in Jeremiah 31. We know Paul is right here because Abraham was seen as righteous in the eyes of God prior to circumcision, or the laws given to Moses, just like the righteous of old such as Noah and Enoch, etc. The Law in its spiritual sense is still binding. Read the Epistle of Barnabas to show how there are legitimate spiritual principles behind the letter of the law that reveal its true spirit. Paul doesn’t preach antinomianism, he actually applies the Torah even stricter, as Jesus does in Matthew 5-7. He is repeating what Jews such as Hillel were saying, that the entirety of the law is founded on loving your neighbor as yourself, which Christ taught too.
